commentBody: Are elephants no longer considered herbivores?  African and Asian elephants are both larger than the white rhino.
Um no thanks I don‚Äôt care about gold stars that much.
48 down is literally wrong. ‚ÄúDo you want to build a snowman‚Äù is literally ANNA singing to Elsa locked away in her room. Bogus crossword puzzle

Enjoyed the cascading "Q"s in the grid!

I hope to never see the phrase "MEAT SWEATS" again in a puzzle, or anywhere else for that matter.

On the easier side for a Saturday. Finished this one faster than my average for Tuesdays.

The diagonal run of Q words in the SE corner was interesting. I was expecting it to become part of a larger theme though.
Solid Saturday.  I got that run of Qs about half way through the solve and kept expecting to see some other related letter play, maybe a run of Xs, more Qs or other less common letters.

The fact that some of the streets in the oldest part of Chicago are named for US presidents is a reminder of how young a city Chicago is. The USA was on its 7th president by the time Chicago was founded.

Much like yesterday, I started very slowly, having nothing until I got to 45A - I‚Äôm a Penn Law grad, so QUAKERS was a gimme.  Fortunately the downs were much friendlier, and the puzzle opened up nicely.  I did have that‚Äôs a trap before THATSAWRAP.

I liked the diagonal string  of 4 Qs in the SE.

MEATSWEATS are something I‚Äôm trying to erase from my memory.

Loved the Q-uartet of Qs!

Had IllbeTHERE before IMSOTHERE, but I was impressed with myself for getting 1D and 30D correct with only a few letters. 

52A I really wanted to be HOLYguacamole, even though that's too long. I also had a brain glitch when I had HOLY_MO_ES and my brain couldn't get away from "holy Moses" even though that's too short. (I got it eventually though.)

Nice smooth fill for me -- definitely my wavelength.
Easiest Saturday ever, at least for me. Was my fastest solve of the week, yes faster than Monday.

Very enjoyable Saturday, I did get a kick out of the Q corner, enough even to forgive VIBEY and WATERVOLE (OK nothing really wrong with those, just both made me say ‚Äúwhat the heck‚Äù?‚Äîand VIBED and MOLE seemed equally likely.) Those corner stacks were all very smooth and interesting, even if I did have TECHNODRUM before BEAT and SUPERSOLID before SONIC (I have a fast friend, he and I are SUPERSOLID together!) OK, maybe not. I love MEATSWEATS and UPSETALERT although ironically if you have an ALERT is it really an upset? (Technically yes I suppose because a lower ranked team beating a higher ranked one is an UPSET even if you could predict it for some reason).
Last thoughts‚Äîno I still didn‚Äôt remember all the letters in CHARLIXCX, maybe next time‚Äîand don‚Äôt forget poor Marshal submitted this way before the last CHARIXCX call out, so is just as annoyed that it just debuted recently as you may be of having to remember her again (if you are). Finally: nit ALERT‚Äîshouldn‚Äôt ‚Äúsugar‚Äù be capitalized if it‚Äôs a PET NAME? I‚Äôm on the fence‚Äî discuss.
Didn't St. Patrick banish snakes from New York and send them to Washington DC?

I think the block saying

HOLY SMOKES!
UPSET ALERT:
MEAT SWEATS

makes a vivid image of a BBQ gone horribly wrong.  Fill in your own particulars.

After my first across pass, I settled in for a long Saturday slog, but  a couple of long down clues really unlocked the majority of the puzzle for me, leading to a new Saturday personal best time!

Great, fun puzzle, thanks, Marshal!

Toughie, and I had WILDEBEEST for 30D for a long while, the I realized they are not endangered. 

L
I loved the Qs and got done in a reasonable time However, I  got no happy music. Finally had to look it up and found that I had WATERMOLE instead of WATERVOLE. Which is why MIBEY seemed so odd.
The grid design is too evocative of a swastika for my taste.
PB today!

I suppose I can see that somebody might find this puzzle easy, but it sure wasn't for me.

In fact, there was no way I was going to get the WATERVOLE/VIBEY cross without some shenanigans.  I was pretty sure it was WATERVOLE or WATERmOLE, so I put an "M" in and ran the alphabet on _IBEY.  When that didn't work, I tried the same with VOLE, and voila!

Still it feels like a cheap win.

Trying to decide what the Whine List will be for today (wow, yesterday DERMA and GENESET really lite a fire under some MD booties).

I'm afraid that somehow the all-knowing AMA has noted this, and the next time I see my doctor she's going to say "I see you failed to show proper deference to medical professionals, your superiors."

CHARLIXCX killed me the last time, but not this time, but maybe it'll be a whine.  

Or maybe there'll be chapter and verse that the Polynesians haven't considered TARO sacred for decades.

Or "how are you supposed to get HOLYSMOKES from ["That's crazy"]

Or, I've eaten tons of BBQ, and never once got MEATSWEATS.

I thought it was a good puzzle, with portions way out of my experience (I am not a gamer at all, so QBERT might as well be IXEXH.

Liked the Q quartet.  That was cute.

I was TSO confused. I really thought the clue must be wrong but I knew it wouldn‚Äôt be and couldn‚Äôt be so‚Ä¶ something else is obviously going on here. 

My train of thought:

‚ÄúZuo‚Äù means many things in Chinese - most basically some easy words like ‚Äúdo‚Äù and ‚Äúsit‚Äù (N«ê zu√≤ sh√©nme?: what are you doing?; Q«êng zu√≤: please sit down).

But hang on: Surely the NYT does not expect us to speak rudimentary Chinese as well as a smattering of French, Spanish, Latin, German and, er‚Ä¶ British English? (And perhaps a little Russian - although there have been mixed signals on that front in recent days, with SOVIET a correct translation of ‚Äúcouncil‚Äù but the letters on Drago‚Äôs outfit are surely SSSR and not CCCP, unless we are writing in Cyrillic?) New York is a melting pot but not all its denizens are superpolyglots!

Then I wondered if I had misunderstood ‚Äútransliterates‚Äù. My insomniac brain ached. 

So I did what any solver does and I left it to stew. And in the end I was saved by the down clues. Aha!! Now I get it! 

Very good crossword!
40 years ago, I never would‚Äôve guessed my Qbert addiction would pay off for me

Feeling pretty good after navigating this one.  On the first pass I wasn't at all certain I'd be able to solve it without some help from Google.  Believe it or not, the diagonal of Qs in the SE were what gave me a foothold and got me started.  Enjoyed it!
That was a wild ride. Thanks. MIBEY was my last correction and I got it. Woohooo. Took the best part of an half hour but yeeeeah.

Found this to be difficult overall.  The NW corner was brutal for me.  Kept thinking of sherbets but no sorbets, for some odd reason.  The pop culture references pretty much everywhere were things I didn‚Äôt know.  But in the spirit of a good loser, I‚Äôll say it was a well-constructed and appropriate Saturday.
I just thought Ratty was a rat.

"Okay, we've just finished filming our movie on giving gifts. That's a wrap!"

(Now they'll take a bow.)

This one was out of my age grade.  I finished it, but was at sea a lot of the time. The Q's helped me hobble through much of it, but I had to consult Dr. G for Charli XCX and a couple of others.

Let us bury MEATSWEATS forever, please.  I grew up eating BBQ, and never, in all my 91 years, did I ever, ever hear of that, far less ever have one. Maybe the most vulgar, disgusting term I've ever seen in a crossword.  Ugh.

Apart from those few quibbles, you gave us a good quizzing, Marshal, and thank you.  Come back again soon (but leave the you-know-what back wherever you found it).
This took me back to the meatwave of ‚Äò03! https://theonion.com/dozens-dead-in-chicago-area-meatwave-1819566849/

for me, more a leisurely postprandial  than the usual adrenaline-fueled, fretful, pricked-up-eared, wary-of-lurking-predators saturday savanna graze.

i think the quaintly corruscating column of qs helped.
New commenter here- but  Anna asked ‚Äúdo you want to build a snowman?‚Äù  Not elsa
I see TESSERACT climbing up the middle "staircase" and then down, balancing the Qs. Probably just a coincidence...or it it? Such a cool word -- a wrinkle in spacetime.

I didn't love this one, not least because the clue for 13D feels grammatically incorrect to me, and that took me out of the grid for a bit.

I strongly feel the clue should be "Lack of trouble." That would yield a noun, instead of the adjective suggested by the existing clue.

That said, I didn't mind the four Qs in a diagonal row. That was fun.

But the rest of this grid was just...okay to me.
Very cool Saturday puzzle, and the q's were a great touch. Good one!

Q Q Q Q

Felt so wrong going for it until it was very obviously correct.

I need to stop doing the puzzle before my morning coffee. I stared and stared at the finished grid and wondered how on earth I‚Äôd never tried SPICE DALES? Good grief. 

Also, quick, someone please tell me that MEAT SWEATS are just an odd item of ACTIVE WEAR‚Äîotherwise, ugh, too gross to contemplate. 

Maybe it‚Äôs the non-vegetarian VIBE, the early Saturday morning VIBE for me, or having to spell CHARLIXCX again (always too soon), but this wasn‚Äôt my grid. I liked yesterday‚Äôs fill; today‚Äôs‚Äîjust somehow less so. 

Have a good weekend, everyone.

Is somebody VIBEY eelier or less eely than somebody non-VIBEY? Methinks crosswordese has struck again? Or is this something living people actually say?

I had to look up the Nestle product but other than that I enjoyed the solve. Having NOTnow rather than NOT YET slowed me down but once I realized my mistake I finished quickly. This probably means @B will decry this as a Wednesday, at best üòÉ

Noticing the string of Q's actually helped me solve. A gimmick, but a welcome one, ultimately.

VIBEY and QBERT aren‚Äôt part of my world, not sure where I‚Äôd pick up that slang term and having stopped playing video games after space invaders. I was never good enough to become interested. 

Spent a while trying to get a VOLE to be a mole. 

The Q ladder accelerated the process. 

A fair Saturday morning puzzle 

Thanks

Any puzzle that includes lots of Qs is automatically a winner in my eyes. I‚Äôve mentioned my affinity for the letter before. I have 2 of them in my name. I have a file of puzzle ideas, and Ode to the letter Q was on it. I guess that‚Äôs out the window ü§£  I initially had Athleisure for ACTIVEWEAR and VIBEd before VIBEY, but otherwise this was a very smooth fill. 
I completed this puzzle while sitting on the plane that was taking me from LAX to PHX to see my son for his birthday. Well, I finished it well before the plane left due to the 3.5 hour delay. The incoming plane was 45 minutes late to LAX. Then there was a leak on one side of the plane that maintenance had to fix and test. Then our captain timed out for the day, so we had to wait for another pilot. Then someone vomited on the plane and maintenance had to return to replace seat cushions and seatbelts. About 15 people decided to cancel their flight at that point and got off. Then they had to confirm each person who was still on the plane. Twice. You can‚Äôt make this stuff up!!! I could have driven here faster than it took from the time I left my house for the airport to the time my plane finally departed and landed üò°ü§¨ At least I get to see him this weekend, just bummed that I missed his birthday dinner üò¢

A note about the MEAT SWEATS. There is a simple explanation. Protein requires more energy (calories) to digest than fats or carbs, generating more heat, which makes you sweat to cool down. People on the Keto diet are prone to get the meat sweats.

Another easy one. Perhaps a generational thing? Thank you Times Rita for explaining where I can see the constructor pictures.

I loved all the Qs! And Holy Smokes was cute.

After reading ‚Äúwho‚Äôs asked ‚Äòdo you want to build a snowman‚Äô‚Äù three times, I decided it‚Äôs ambiguous. It could be ‚Äúwho has asked‚Äù or ‚Äúwho is asked‚Äù so I just filled the A on the bottom and kept going. 

Overall, quick and fun ending to a quick week!

im new here.
and perhaps its already been done.
but id like to lift my glass and propose a toast to sam ezersky and his mini co-elves.
who are frequently responsible for the often delightful petits fours they provide in the minis while im still digesting the maxis.
i suspect that he and the other mini constructors do not get enough credit for their efforts.
just today, for example, mr ezersky crammed "elision" into the tiny morsel.
no small feat on such a small beat.
bravo.

The images that come to mind with MEAT SWEATS are far worse than the actual affliction, I‚Äôm sure. Make it stop.

I like Qs because Qs are twofers. Where there‚Äôs a Q, there‚Äôs a U! (Except when there‚Äôs a Q-BERT or a Q-TIP. D‚Äôoh!)

QUIK brings back bad childhood memories of chalky, overly sweet strawberry milk. I never understood why I couldn‚Äôt have Hershey‚Äôs syrup like a normal kid.

DOES cued as ‚Äúit may go for a buck‚Äù was cute.
I was moderately wowed until I saw those four Qs pop up! Magic moment. An excellent puzzle for that alone.
Hippie Happening - be in? I don‚Äôt get it ü§î

Upper left corner was the last part to fall, mainly cause I couldn't remember what the heck a bandolier is...even though I had just heard the term somewhere. Was it Jeopardy? (Somebody PLEASE notice how clever I am...) Any-old-how, got 'er done in under 24 minutes, which is not bad at all for me on a Saturday.

Regarding the mini - please note that satin is a weave not a fiber. I believe they meant silk. You can have satin in different fibers including polyester (commonly found) or cotton in which case it would end up called a sateen.
Lots of fun but got hung up on bottom middle. Holybjesus  & jar üòú

Fun Saturday! Lots of triple stacks and a staircase of Qs. Nothing too tricky and any errors were quickly exposed. I had Athleisure and Spicewines. Not heard of a BE IN or MEAT SWEATS. One of these days I‚Äôm going to have to see Wicked and Frozen and listen to CHARLI XCX.

Very playful clueing! Good unthemed, Saturday puzzle. Starting in the southeast quadrant, I tried WILDEBEEST,  for 30D, before quickly realizing, from the crosses, the correct animal solution. I also loved all the ‚ÄúQ‚Äù words in that quadrant. And learning the etymology of 22A.
Q-t puzzle! Q up the next one!!

Definitely one of my favourite grid designs in some time (bar the excellent Saturday by Blake Slonecker in June this year).
The edges of the puzzle are wrapped so nicely by combinations of tripled stacked 10- and 4-letter entries, with a small staircase in the middle. Just opening the crossword to see a satisfying design already makes me happy. :)
Pretty remarkable to get three U's like that. Stunning.

As your resident alphadoppeltotter, a role I‚Äôve inexplicably taken in the past eight years, it is my duty to inform you that this puzzle has an unusually low number of double letters, at four, where unusual is any number less than five. This is the fourth time this year that this has happened. 

I remain your humble servant, ever on the alert.

swag at 15 A made me put in I wanna comE at 2 D, and those two decisions slowed things down in the SW.  I knew a bandolier was an AMMO BELT, but tried to think of another word for it.  Coming up blank, I erased my errors, and the rest fell into place.

58 A is natures way of telling you that you should reevaluate your choices in life.

The preponderance of Qs made the SE fall QUITE quickly.

Satisfactory.

I knew Ratty was a water vole, I don't know why.

The hardest for me was I AM SO THERE. Even when the crossers did it, it seemed incomprehensible. 

ENS - I looked this up but see no connection to tennis?
If you got 8 down without looking it up, you definitely get the brownie! üíÉüèªüåü
This is extremely unbalanced and poorly executed. The SW is beyond unapproachable. I still have no idea where to even start. This is after breezing through the rest of the grid in less than 6 mins.

In his first two Times puzzles (today is his third) both Tuesdays, Marshal established himself as a masterful grid manipulator ‚Äì stunt puzzles where the stunt made my jaw drop, made me want to do a standing-O rather than dismiss the puzzle as simply the constructor showing off.  

Many Saturday puzzlers skip Tuesday puzzles; if you are one of them, I strongly suggest you put these on your to-do list: 1/16/24 and 9/9/25.

Some of that manipulation skill carried over into today‚Äôs Q-string, which was delivered so cleanly, even including the gorgeous word QUIVER, that I thought it boosted the puzzle‚Äôs quality, gave it a sparky ping.

That's on top of those four terrific stacks.  Marshal‚Äôs notes indicate that he kept filling, erasing, and redoing them until they passed his bar.  This doesn‚Äôt surprise me; according to his notes, he tooled around on his last Times puzzle for more than a year before he was satisfied with it.

The talent he‚Äôs shown in his trio of puzzles ‚Äì what a start! ‚Äì has me thirsting for more.  Please, Marshal?  And thank you for a terrific outing today!
Anna sang "Do You Want To Build A Snowman", Elsa never sings that lyric. Am I wrong?

oddly similar to solving a new puzzle,
created by‚Ä¶ 
anyone but me!

Apparently, I misdirect myself.

Whew. XWStats rates this puzzle as ‚Äúvery easy,‚Äù and while I solved roughly 35% faster than my Saturday average, this one was no walk in the park for me. Got fairly deep into the grid before I had a fill and then I solved it fairly chaotically, jumping around the grid a lot. I was certain I‚Äôd need a lot of help and would look up quite a few but I was able to avoid any. The OCD part of me admired the diagonal line of Qs in the southeast, and I also appreciated the proximity of HOLY SMOKES (52A) to MEAT SWEATS (58A).

All in all, an enjoyable Saturday workout, so thank you, Marshal Hermann.

On Safari in 1998 I saw what was then considered to be the last white rhino in northern Africa.  But only two  white female rhinos remain in the world, in Kenya's Ol Pejeta Conservancy.  So the only way  to ensure  species survival would be to mate them successfully with southern African white rhino, and if the issue were not male, it would still be in danger of extinction.  I didn't find any information on efforts to do that in my search.

Regarding  today's Wordplay photograph:

Releasing a WATER VOLE into a (dubiously clean) nature reserve by means of a *Pringles can* tells us all we need to know about the contemporary state of the environment.

What a world!

It took me a little while to fill in 16A since techno is one specific genre within electronic music and, like Caitlin, I was looking for an instrument, or something universal, maybe with the word synth in it. The link she gave to the history of techno was interesting to read, as I‚Äôm more of a fan of trance, psytrance, synthpop, and eurodance and haven‚Äôt listened to a ton of techno. It led me down a genre rabbit hole that included reading descriptions of the genres and subgenres of electronic dance music on Reddit, including this gem of a thread on the difference between trance and techno: https://www.reddit.com/r/aves/comments/190wryh/differences_between_techno_and_trance/ I also discovered that Ishkur‚Äôs guide to electronic music, a map of electronica genres and subgenres from the early 2000s (back when it was built using flash) is still online. It was snarky (with a lot of NSFW language), so it was originally sent to me as a joke, but it was also the most comprehensive guide that existed back then so I remember referencing it from time to time. Not quite done with the puzzle yet‚Äîit is all filled in but I‚Äôve got a typo somewhere I still need to find‚Äîbut I‚Äôm close enough to the end to say I really enjoyed this one, as well as the Tuesday with vowels in every other square that the constructor had published in September. Thanks, Marshal, for a satisfying solve!

Shoutout for the Xs and Qs! Great stack answers horizontally and vertically. I was able to navigate around my initial entries of CLICKTRACK at 16A and ATHLEISURE and WILDEBEEST at 29D and 30D (no idea if the wildebeest is endangered). Very enjoyable!

Here‚Äôs to hoping Marshall‚Äôs debut puzzle is also his last. I am not a fan.

I appreciate that the constructor studiously avoided the stale Chinese menu clue for General TSO. I will spare you all my usual rant about old and new Romanization systems colliding in the style guide. Instead, I will inform you that Zuo Zongtong was a real general of the Qing Dynasty, who was instrumental in suppressing the Taiping Rebellion. Later on, he was a highly successful administrator, introducing reforms in agriculture, the textile industry, and education. It is not known whether he was a chef.

The delicious chicken dish was created in the '50s by a chef from Hunan named Peng Changkuei who fled to Taiwan with the Nationalists, and later immigrated to NYC, where he opened a restaurant. (Kissenger ate there frewuently.) Master Peng went back to his hometown in the '90s, and finally introduced General Tso's chicken to the Chinese people.

A little kiss-n-tell:
My Partner had a youth deprived of the Classics of children's literature. When I first was getting to know him, he invited me up to his place "Up North," on a small (90 acre) inland lake. It was a sunny, summer afternoon. First we went around the lake on the pontoon boat, then we paddled a bit in the tandem kayak, then we took out the paddle boat.
"I just love being out on the water, messing about in boats," he said.
"Oh my G.d, you *are* the Water Rat!" I said, "you even look like him!" (He has sandy brown hair.)
"I'm no rat!" he exclaimed.
"No, you don't understand, it's from *the Wind in the Willows*, and the Water Rat is a very good character--one of the heroes, in fact. Of course, that would make me the Mole, and I'm not sure I like that."

Well, as a pet name, it never stuck, but I will have to inform him that, technically, he is the Water Vole!

Yeah, the clue doesn‚Äôt strictly make sense. You can‚Äôt transliterate something that‚Äôs already a transliteration into the same target writing system.

I guess the thinking was that something like ‚ÄúAlternative transliteration of the Chinese surname ‚ÄòZuo‚Äô‚Äù isn‚Äôt Saturday-level, maybe? Obviously, they couldn‚Äôt actually go with ‚ÄúChinese surname transliterating Â∑¶,‚Äù which would actually make sense. (I know we‚Äôve had clues where ‚ÄòH‚Äô is supposed to be interpreted as a Greek eta, as well as the aforementioned Cyrillic-as-Latin thingy, but a clue requiring hanzi knowledge would be fair only to a small subset of NYT crossword solvers.)

Presenting Pinyin in a clue to solve to the Wade-Giles representation that‚Äôs more familiar to the average American takeout-orderer is already reasonably difficult unless you happened to have studied Sinology at university, so I don‚Äôt think they needed to reword the clue in the way I think they might have, if that was the case.

If the NYT crossword was a massage parlor, Saturday is not a day for a light touch. Rather than misdirection, I'd call this one confusion.  Roman letters cannot be transliterated into Roman letters.  To be the second to quote Inigo Montoya today, "I don't think it means what you think it means."
